segments.text: And where were you born?
In Rollins, Wyoming, on July 17, 1930.
And where were your parents born?
My mother was born in Hakona, in Michoacan, and my father in La Barca, Jalisco.
My father in 1894, and my mother in 1900, but that must never be revealed.
And she left Mexico, I believe.
Now, I'm unclear as to the year.
I think it was 1913.
My father left in 1919.
And where did they meet?
In my hometown of Rollins, Wyoming.
My father was working for the Union Pacific Railroad at the time, and my mother had been widowed three years before she remarried my father.
And I've just only learned that my father knew her while she was still married to her first husband, which is something I hadn't realized before.
I would say roughly about 1925, I suppose, is when they met, and then we married in 1929.
I was the first born at that moment.
Now, what was your mother's name?
Guadalupe Navarro.
Guadalupe Navarro.
She was 13, let's see, she would have been 13 years old in 1913.
Now, did she ever tell the story of how she and her family happened to leave Mexico?
Yeah, I think that, first of all, her older brother had migrated to the United States a few years earlier and homesteaded a ranch in Wyoming.
And then when the Revolution came with all the problems, rather than stay there with the violence,
Apparently my grandmother decided to move to Wyoming where her son was.
And so my mother, my grandmother, made a trip sometime before 1913 to come up to Wyoming and see what the situation was.
Then she returned to Mexico and brought my mother and two of her grandchildren who had been born and abandoned by an elder daughter.
And so the four of them made the trip home without us.
And your grandfather was no longer living?
No, my grandfather died in 1923, but my mother's grandfather separated from him for reasons which are unclear to me.
But it's always struck me as a bit strange that she would leave her husband to go to her son.
But it's not really strange because her husband, my mother's father, was her second husband.
Her first husband had died.
His name was Emiliano Javitegui.
It's a is a Basque derivation, .
Well, anyhow.
So this was .
Yeah.
They met and married.
Apparently, yeah.
I know very little, very unclear.
Then she married again, and- My mother was born to the marriage.
Was it in 1913 that she left her husband to go to the States?
Apparently so, yeah.
Well, whatever happened to him, to your grandfather?
He died in 1923, natural causes.
What was his name?
What was his name?
I don't know his first name.
His last name, I don't know.
No father.
Yeah.
I'm sure my mother's told me I forgot him.
But he stayed there in the church?
Yes, yeah.
And according to my mother, he stayed, I suppose, because he didn't want to play second fiddle to his eldest stepson, probably.
But he apparently wasn't disturbed by the violence that was life in Mexico at the time.
And mom says that he himself had experienced threats.
One of the stories she tells about Mexicans, she has very little opinion of Mexicans, even though she was out there as
although she's nationalized in Massachusetts, is that the violence was just unbelievable.
That apparently, during the early phase of the revolution, she interposed with her body a pistol that was threatening her.
And she doesn't like me being in El Paso because it's too close to Mexico and Mexico didn't believe that.
And so I think this sort of indicates her attitude toward Mexico.
It's one in which she sees violence everywhere.
And this, you think, comes out of her experiences during the first two or three years of the revolution.
She tells stories about la vistas y los casancistas.
And I don't know if these are firsthand, because I get the idea that Villa and...
and Carranza didn't have their fallout until after she left the country.
No, they wouldn't have.
Yeah, you see, and therefore, some of this may be hearsay, but anyhow, she tells about, you know, she recites a little poem to me.
When the vistas would take the village, they'd say, are you vistas?
And the poor people would say, well, we're neither vistas nor carancistas, just poor workers, you know.
But there was a little rhyme, which sounds very enchanting in Spanish, which I've forgotten it.

But this, I think, is the atmosphere that she conjures when she thinks of Mexico, and why she's reluctant to go back, and reluctant to have her children identify very much with Mexico, where Americans is what she's concerned.
And she has never been back since 1913?
No, she went back in 19...
When did I say her father died?
Mm-hmm.
Yeah.
So she went back prior, a year or two before he died.
That's the only business she's been in ever since.
So it would be, she left in 1913, was back within 10 years, and has returned.
And when I press her, you know, I myself really wasn't too concerned with my Mexican background until I suppose I was an adult.
And when I do ask her questions,
I was very young, and I don't remember.
But these things do come out in informal conversations when she's not a daughter.
For example, the reason Ed Leonard may have mentioned you to you was I remarked to him that at Christmas time, I got a letter from Mom that she was in El Paso in 1913, something like this.
And apparently, on that trip, she relayed this at a different time.
The train on which they were riding had been derailed or stopped for some reason.
And so she and my cousins and my grandmother walked for several days.
And she tells me about how my grandmother would put a handkerchief in pools of water they had collected so she could drink the water without getting the impediments that had been there.
And that finally, they were rescued

by Villa's troops to the extent that a cavalry detachment apparently came on them as they were walking across and directed them to a rail point at which there was a train waiting or was going to come and pick them up.
And so her opinion of Villa is very high because she associates this cavalry detachment with them.
And she tells the story of how my grandmother went to the captain of the detachment.
My mother then was just obviously in her puberty.
And told the captain that, you know, her daughter was, you know, she didn't want the soldiers molesting her.
And the captain...
let me know that she would not be molested, or he posted the guard.
I can't remember who it was, you know, to prevent her from being molested, which is another reason that she could explain her high regard for the idea of being molested.
But this is the sum total of my recollections from the millennium, except the recollection about how nice it was to have certain kinds of fruit in Mexico over the wine season, in this case.
Now, what did your grandfather do in Hacona?
What was his occupation?
He was apparently a clerk, but a white-collar worker in a store.
Now, Mom is very proud of her Spanish ancestry and says that he came, he apparently, I asked her point-blank whether he came from Spain.
She didn't know, but she was always pointing out that he was, you know, a Spaniard.
It's the wrong thing to admit to these days, but at that time, she's very proud to have it, still is.
And she didn't know.
She said that if he hadn't come over from Spain himself, he was the firstborn of parents who had come from Spain, in the same way I am the firstborn of parents who came from Mexico.
But he was, apparently, a white-collar worker.
She's always been very proud that he could read, write, calculate.
She'd say, my father could add figures in his head.
She was very proud of his occupation or his skill, which I suppose at that time was something to be proud of.
My grandmother was uneducated, I think.
So she doesn't talk about your grandmother's background?
No.
Apparently, my grandmother married

I don't know why she married my grandfather, but apparently the big love in her life was her first life with Mianito, because I can remember listening to Mianito this, Mianito that, you know, all the time I was growing up.
I would never have messed with my own grandfather.
And so I have a hunch that it must have been a marriage or something, you know, that she needed someone to help her raise a family or for financial reasons.
Now, let's see, do I have your, your grandfather's name was?
Navarro.
Navarro.
Oh, that's right.
Navarro.
Now, you may be confused because I said my grandmother's first husband was in How They Can Eat.
Right.
That's her first husband.
Now, after going to Wyoming, what did your grandmother do?
Apparently, she worked.
She took in washing.
She cooked in either a boarding house or a restaurant.
I don't know.
Until, I guess she did that until her own children had gotten jobs and were married and caught supporting her.
And then she lived with their assistants until she died in 1953, the age of 94 years.
Now, your mother married...
Her first husband.
Her first husband.
Who was he?
His name was Manuel Ayala.
He was also of Mexican descent, but I believe he was born in the United States.
I'm not that sure.
And he was, he worked on the railroad in the roundhouse, if that makes any sense to you.
apparently helped keep the machinery in running order.
I suppose a mechanic of sorts, I'm not sure what the technical name is.
And this was shortly after she got to Wyoming?
No, she married him in 1919.
So it was a period of six years from the time she went home until she married at the age of 19.
And she helped my grandmother take the Russians.
Apparently she started schooling now.
My grandmother took her out into third grade because

She happened to be walking with a boy, and my grandmother thought this was something a young lady shouldn't do, so she pulled her out of school and kept her on the very close of her bed until she married her first husband.
And she had four children by that marriage.
Four children by that marriage.
And then she married your father.
Yes.
Her first husband died.
Died.
He died in 1927 of...
The physician who operated on him for tonsils apparently cut an artery.
Yeah, that's right.
My mother's first husband, probably her life died, and she's never found a way to replace him, even though she'd been married to him.
Then she married my father, I think in 1929, and I was born in 30, and there were three children from that time.
There were four children, and one of them died.
What was your father's first name?
Jesus Jose Gomez.
And the children were?
Me, Rudolph, and I had a younger brother named Ruben, and he had all the names that had been emphasized, you know, except my own in the birth certificate.
Now, your father, Jesus, you say left Mexico in 1919.
Yes.
Where was he from?
He was from La Barca in Jalisco.
And?
All I know about his background is that he, I think he was a woodcutter's son and a woodcutter himself in Mexico until the revolution came along.
And then his activities during the revolution are very unclear.
Now, I've heard rumors to the effect that he had a wife who was over in Mexico.
and that either abandoned them or were separated from them from the revolution.
I don't know.
This is hearsay.
But I have a hunch it's probably accurate, you know.
And I hope there's never going to be another way to forgive me.
But I have a hunch that it's accurate.
I just, I don't know.
And it's only been very recently that I know from a pretty reliable source, which is the first cousin, that apparently he was
somehow supportive of Villa's effort in northern Mexico.
But this is hearsay evidence.
I don't know.

I can recall my father talking with his friends also from Mexico about the revolution and talking about how they would do this, how to bury the dead and how they would be sure to take the shoes from the dead before they're buried and this kind of thing.
But no account
which could be historically accurate of what he did for those years of the revolution.
I have a much better picture of what my uncle, Alveo, always did.
He was one of Villa's men and was with Villa when they raided Columbus, New Mexico in 1950.
This is your father's brother?
My father's brother, Aurelio.
A-U-R-E-L-L-I-O.
And he was in the detachment that raided Columbus, New Mexico in 1950, and was also with Villa when they were being chased by Pershing.
And he used to recount the story of how they surprised the American detachment and took their uniforms from them and returned them to the United States in their long underwear.
And he says, you'll never read about that in an American history book.
And the fact that he said this long before I was very prideful of my Mexican heritage leads me to believe it was probably an accurate statement.
And it's true.
I've never read about it in American history.
No, I haven't either.
But he said they did this.
They caught this detachment, didn't want to kill them.
They were in that trouble.
Took the uniforms, the firearms, gave them their horses, and sent them back to town in their underwear, which would be hilarious.
Yeah.
So I have a hunch that he was probably one of Eden's regularers.
But again, I didn't have enough presence of mine.
I was very young.
He died in 1943.
I didn't have enough presence or enough sense of history to really probe.
And so it's lost.
It's terrible.
Well, now, when did he come to?
I presume this was in Wyoming?
Yeah.
He and my father worked together on Union Pacific Railroad.
And I have a hunch they probably crossed
My father, he and my father worked together on the railroad until, I suppose, my father married my mother.
And then my Uncle Aurelio finally located in Longmont, Colorado, and worked there in the farms until 1941 or 42 when he contracted tuberculosis, or had been suffering from it anyhow.
He came to Wyoming in 1941.
He was living with my father at the time of Pearl Harbor up there.
This is how I dated.
We all remember what happened on Joe Harmon.
So he was living with my father in 1941, and he lived with him until he died in 1943.
And as I say, by the time I knew him, he was a very gaunt man, very wasted.
But I have a cousin who tells me that at the time he was working with my father and my uncle, my grandfather was distinguished by the fact that he was so tall.
very strappy.
But this was long before I knew either, long before I knew my father.
Now your grandfather's on your father's side.
No?
Yes, I know nothing about him.
I know his name.
What's his name?
Sin Poroso.
I take that to be S-I-N-F-O-R-O-S-O.
Sin Poroso Gomez.
I know nothing about him.
except that he was, I think, a woodcutter, because my father talked about going, taking the mule, and cutting wood, and coming back, and all this kind of stuff.
I don't know a thing about my grandmother, except at one time, my father was very ill. She stole into an hacienda and stole some oranges from the trees.
He would repeat this about how his mother really loved him.
So I have a hunch there was a pretty hard life, much harder life for my father than for my mother.
From for I believe to deduce that they were probably considered to be lower middle class.
My father was just complete .
But yet he was, I think, probably, he taught himself to read or was taught.
He had some schooling because he could read Spanish.
That's his book up there.
And he cut himself to read the English newspapers at home so he could keep up with the news.
But I thought I had a picture here.
It was very strange to me that neither one of my parents spoke much of Mexico.
Now, it may be that they've been away from it for so long.
But then there was the usual racial prejudice in my hometown.
And so it may have been that they
How did your father happen to leave?
Did he leave in any way because of the revolution or did he just leave?
It's difficult to say.
I think probably there's a combination of factors.
I'm pretty well accepted in my own mind that my uncle Adrian wasn't a beast.
And I think that my father was probably a vista of the camp followers riot, you know, cooking, this kind of thing, being a hostler or something.
And when Villa had lost, you know, in Salaya in 1915, apparently there was this banding.
Excuse me.
Hi.
Hey.
Come on, let's go to class.
Oh, excuse me, I'm...
I just came by to see if you wanted to go today.
Oh, well, thank you very much.
No, I've got this.
Hello, how are you?
Hello.
And...
I think it was probably the culmination of the tumult in Mexico, the fact that he had been more or less active.
Excuse me, would you like a mask?
Please feel free.
I think that may have had something to do with it.
And the fact that there just wasn't anything economically that he could do in Mexico, and as you know,
There's always been economic opportunity inside of the Rio Grande.
And I think probably there's a combination of factors.
But he never said, I left Mexico because.
It was when I left Mexico.
And it would be nice to go back and revisit this kind of thing.
But now that he's gone.
I've had a chance to reflect on all this.
I'm the only member of my family who's ever gone to college, you see.
And so a great deal of my interest is academic, you know, since I've been exposed to some of this myself.
And I've puzzled over why they didn't talk about their background and their families, because it's a tremendous loss to us, not to know much about ourselves.
And I've never been able to answer it satisfactorily for my father.
For my mother, I think that she was very conscious of being an alien in Wyoming.

wanted to make things as easy for us as possible, so she insisted that we speak English as quickly as we started in the library, that we assimilate as rapidly as possible, as she deprecated and downplayed our Mexican background, which I think is regrettable now.
It's taken me 30 years to reach this point.
But my father was self-consciously proud of being a Mexican.
I can remember whenever anything favorable about Mexico came up, he would always
bring to our attention in the newspaper.
He would tune in to Spanish radio broadcasts, this kind of thing.
I just don't know why he didn't speak with us about it.
Part of the reason may have been that he and my mother didn't have a happy marriage.
I mentioned to my uncle, I read him living in my father's house.
They were separated practically all my life.
And so it may have been that
You know, when we were together, there were more immediate things to talk about in his background.
I just don't know.
I have often thought of going to Mexico and see if I have, you know, see if I could locate my family there.
But I'm not half afraid to, you know, because I'm not sure I really want to know.
Here I can romanticize and fantasize.
It's probably much more appealing the truth would be.
But I don't know.
Now your father, he worked on the railroads.
Was he still working?
How long, when did your father die?
He died in 1946.
And was he still working on the railroads?
No, he was working on the railroad as a section hand when he met my mother.
But before that he had done, you know, the usual sorts of things that Mexican immigrants do.
He had been a sheep herder.
He had to pick beets in Colorado.
He had worked in the agricultural field in Stockton, California.
He had done some sort of work in Portland, Oregon.
He worked on the railroad in Auburn, Utah, and was on the section in Wyoming where he met my mother.
And then in the mid-'30s, he contracted Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever.
And of course, it couldn't work, so he lost his job at the railroad.
And at that time, they didn't have a workman's compensation.
So he lost his job.
And he was hired back by the railroad, I think in 1938 or 1939, without any credit given him for the seniority he'd already accumulated.
So he was bitter about that.
And during the war, he had an opportunity to work at the oil refinery in Rollins, Wyoming, or in Sinclair, Wyoming, which is seven miles from the hometown of Rollins.
And he worked there from 1942 until his death in 1946.
And your mother, what did she do all these years when she was separated from your father?
Did he support you?
He supported us.
She didn't work?
She didn't work.
She worked from the time her first husband died until she married my father.
She worked as a janitor of a little school there, a little sophomore school.
She took him washing and did, I suppose, what would be maid's work.
But she finished that when my father died.
or she quit that, apparently she married my father, and didn't work during their marriage.
Now, during the time that he was ill, we were on welfare.
And this probably explains the reason I'm a Democrat, and my father was a Roosevelt Democrat, because we were held by the Spanish program.
And then she didn't work again until we had all left home.
We were all, I suppose, trying to make our ends meet,
And she worked for a while at the hospital there at home as a cook, this kind of thing.

She remarried after my father died a third time, a man named Percy Sanchez, who was of Mexican descent, but he was born in Colorado, an American, served in the American Army during the First World War, and had a pretty good job
for a Mexican American in that he was a founder of Hatchfield.
Thank you.
And he died, I can't remember, 1961, 62.
Anyhow, my mother is, her major source of income today is his social security and whatever her children can send her to.
Ah, now.
Okay, well, I was saying that that
you know, her major source of income is Social Security.
And then, you know, I send her a contribution each month.
I think several of her other children do.
And then my sister lives in my hometown, and she makes the biggest contribution of all, which is looking after her, you know, taking care of her.
How old is your mother now?
But she's not been in good health over the last four years.
So I suppose what I'm saying is that her major source of money income is Social Security.
The psychic income is from my sister, and then the in-between from the rest of the children, of which seven are surviving.
You said you were the only one, seven.
I hear that she only had seven.
No, I said that she had four Gomez children, but the little girl died in 1934.
I have a sister who died in 1934.
Oh, okay.
She had four Gomez children.
Four Gomez and four Ayala.
One of the Gomez children died.
And then your brothers and sisters, Rudolfo, that's you.
Ruben, and how did you happen to go to college?
You said you were the only one who had gone.
I was only complete.
I had an older brother who went.
That was one of the Alaya.
Ayala.
Ayala.
Yes.
A-Y-A-L-A.
I don't know.
I've asked myself that question.
It's just the luck of the draw.
Some genes I got.
My older brother got all the business genes in the family.
He's a very successful realtor in Oregon.
So it's genes I get.
Well, you were talking about prejudice in Rollins, Wyoming.
I don't have, in fact, Wyoming's one of the few states I've only been to a tiny bit.
First of all, were there very many people of Mexican origin in Wyoming?
Yes, uh-huh.
Yes, to the extent my hometown, I think, probably the time I was born in 1930, the time I was first conscious of, the population probably varied from 4,000 to 5,000 people.
Even now, it's only 8,000, I think.
But the entire south side of Rollins at the time I was growing up was Mexican, Mexican-American.
And these were Mexicans primarily who had come over from old Mexico and settled.
Because we made a distinction between, we called them suramacos.
You're probably familiar with the term.
This is people who came from Mexico to the United States.
And los manitos, who were Mexicans from New Mexico or Colorado.
who migrated to Rollins.
So we made a distinction between Mexican-Mexican Americans and American-Mexican Americans.
No, I don't think I've heard those terms, but that may be... Sudomato.
S-U-R-U-M-A-T-O.
And this is from a hacienda in Michoacn.
And this is the name they gave themselves to indicate their Mexican origin.
And Los Magnitos...
There's a publication on Manico culture.

And these are Spanish people who live in New Mexico and southern Colorado, who have been in the country probably for hundreds of years, and their descendants, perhaps, of Spanish and Indians, or perhaps are of Mexican lineage, but their forebears came over considerably before the Sudamatos, from whom I'm descended.
Yeah, but it was perhaps in the late 19th century.
Or early, you know, I don't know, you know, maybe the Mexican War.
I just don't know, but I knew, though, that the distinction was made when I was growing up.

And the most cutting thing we could say about another Mexican was that he was a manito, you see, because we wanted to indicate that we were really the best Mexicans because our parents had just come over from Mexico.
Oh, that's interesting.
Yeah, it is.
You know, we discriminated against ourselves amongst ourselves as well.
You mentioned an hacienda in Michoacn as having given sura matos.
Suru.
The way I've got it spelled.
It may be this.
Yeah, this right here.
Now, I got this information from a publication by Manuel Gamil.
Are you familiar with some of his works?
I think that's where I got it.
Something I've read, though, explained the origin of this term, which I knew from the time I was very young, but I didn't know what it was.
I just thought,
You know, they're from Missouri, you know, from South Mexico.
This isn't it.
He says that this was from a hacienda.
This is the name of a hacienda in Michoacn.

And apparently it became a concept or a symbol to indicate the origin of these people in the United States who had come directly from Mexico rather than being of Mexican descent, you know, filtered through several generations who had lived in the country before them.
Well, this is interesting because I've never picked up
either one of these terms from East Texas or South Texas.
There wouldn't be very many people from New Mexico.
There would be Texans who were here, Tejanos who were here before the Texas Revolution, many of them.
But I wonder, there may be a very real geographical difference here in the use of terms.
Now, again, I wish I had the source at my fingertips.
I think it's got me, but it may be somewhere else.
But in the literature...
There is the term, surumato, and they say it's from a hacienda in Michoacan.
Now, this I've got from the literature.
Someone has got, maybe it's Campa, Maynard Campa has done something about it.
Someone, you know, it is in the literature.
I was, well, I've already apologized for not being able to read the explanation.
Well, what, how many of the people in your hometown were from Michoacan?
I don't know.
I don't know.
I don't know.

We had, I suppose that we didn't have very many friends because my uncle's family was a large one and my mother's family, you know, and I suppose our primary friendship, my first memories of any sort of socialization with cousins, you know.
But our friends, I suppose, were the Macias, who were also from Old Mexico, Los Canos from Old Mexico,
I suppose these were the closest friends we had.
I don't know where they were from, except that they were from old Mexico and maybe from where my parents came from.
If you look at the map, it meets La Barca and Hacona aren't too far apart.
No, they're not.
Isn't Hacona where Cardenas loves it or Cardenas is from?
I don't know.
I don't know.
There was no talk of kindness?
Oh, my father, yes, yes.
But no, not in a reasonable sense, you know.
But kindness, you know, in my father's hierarchy of values would rank very high before I had any formal education at all.
You know, kindness was present in the 34th and 40th, you know.
I knew about him just as much as I knew about Abraham Lincoln.
These were in my pantheon of heroes.
And so my father, as I mentioned, was very prideful of his ancestry and background, and was extremely proud of what Cardenas had done.
And I'm quite sure I may be intellectualizing and reading into the record something that wasn't there, but it seems to me that he was very proud of the expropriation.
And any time the gringos got out, my father was very happy.
And yes, there was knowledge, pride, even in Aleman, you know, just because he's a Mexican president.
But not regional pride, but he may well have been from Michoacan.
Oh, he was from Michoacan.
I wasn't sure at the time.
Your father kept up with events in Mexico.
Did your mother pay any attention?
Listen, I've...
No, mom was sort of home, housewife-oriented.
My father, my mother, again, this is probably post-facto research, has said that apparently, she said, well, you get your ability to speak in public from your father.
And apparently, on Mexican holidays, they would have a gathering.
My father would give talks, and other people would give talks.
So I have deduced from this that he was illiterate in the formal sense, although he could read and write.
But I would consider him to be sort of an intellectual in the sense of trying to place himself in a larger role, being aware of public events.

Writing poetry, he wrote poems, love poems to my mother, which is something I suppose all of us do, but to have a man of that background, I think, indicates that he did have an interest in education, sympathy, which probably couldn't be said about a great many of his contemporaries.
Your father was predominantly of Spanish background.
No, no.
My father was very, very dark, very Indian.
He was very Indian.
Was he Tarascon, perhaps?
Or do you know what?
I don't know.
Here's a picture of my mother and my uncle Tony.
You see?
Mm-hmm.
He's a Haute-A-Tahiti.
They took off the Tahiti and made it Haute-A-Tahiti when he was in the United States.
Wow.
My father was very Indian.
If there's someone... Now, look, this... Fine, thank you.
Now, this is the only thing I have from my father's...
These clippings and everything in here are his, and this sort of argument is the point I'm making about his interest.
Was he actually from the town of La Barca, or was he from a rancho nearby?
That might make a difference.
I don't know.
La Barca is all I know.
I know that there are some towns there.
Los Altos de Jalisco is near there.
I just glimpsed this thing.
Well, go ahead, if I find it all.
I thought I had a small picture, which I had glued in here years and years ago.
But no, he was not primarily Spanish.
I think he was mestizo, obviously.
And it was quite dark.
But linguistically, fully Spanish.
Oh, fluent.
And he commanded it.
As the Spaniards say, he was a dominio all the way.
Spoke it very well.
I'm curious about the manifestation of prejudice in Wyoming.
Was it something that you sensed very greatly as a child?
Yes, yes.
We were all sent, you know, we had a Mexican school.
Now, this was explained, this was geographic, but as quickly as we got to the fifth grade, you know, we all went to the central school.
And...
I don't know.
I grew up hearing the dirty Mexican bit, the greaser.
What else were some of the things?
We all carried knives.
All the stereotypes that you associate with prejudice were there.
And we became very conscious at some early age, obviously, because I can remember being conscious of being Mexican all my life in a defensive sense.
I don't know the source.
He's the one who put it in.
Did your family remain Catholic?
Oh, yes.
I am a bad one, but I'm Catholic.
You know, it's stuff that a laborer...
of that vintage wouldn't survive.
Church situation throughout the states of Mexico.
In other words, he was concerned with things.
Yes, yes.
And he was very proud of what the Revolution accomplished in the long run.
Yeah, yeah.
Did he ever think of going back to Mexico?
No.
He talked of going away from Wyoming, but he said he'd like to live in Ogden, Utah,
or Stockton, California, or Portland, Oregon, each of these towns he had lived in in his younger days when he was with the railroad or something like this.
But never talked about going back to Mexico.
And I think that a great deal of the hesitancy that my family has in owning up to their Mexitanness comes from this instilling at a very early age on the part of my mother more than my father.
somehow a reserve against Mexico, even though he's very proud of what they've done.
He never said, I want to go back to visit.
I don't believe it.
He would fantasize about the food and the fruits they would have.
But never going back for a visit, nor to live.
Which leads me to believe that maybe he did have a family back then, you know, and would be reluctant to go back for that reason.
Because he didn't, as far as you know, have the same kind of traumatic experience that your mother is a 13-year-old.
It's easy to see how she would have that.
Well, you see, at the time of the Revolution, he would already have been a young man.
I suppose a man, given the standards of that age, he would have been...
If you take 1910 as the starting point.
He was younger than his brother, who was with Villa.
And that's what would perhaps put him into this kind of camp following situation.
I've deduced this for myself, both from my recollections and from what my cousins told me about him.
It's very intriguing, and I don't want to pursue it much more, because I'm sure the truth isn't going to be as nice as my imagination.
But I tried to give you a factual account of what I remember and not make them heroes of the revolution or anything like that.
You talked about how you have not been to Mexico except Juarez.
But you did live in South America.
Yes, I lived in Lima.
I was a Fulbright professor at the Catholic University in 1967.
How did you feel about Peru?
Well, I had ambivalent feelings about it.
It was a tremendous professional opportunity.
I enjoyed being in the Spanish culture for the first time in my life.
It was very palpable.
I enjoyed it.
It forced me to renovate my own Spanish.
I think the only reservation I had is I had my family with me, which were two young sons at the time, and my wife, who doesn't, you know, she can speak Spanish.
She doesn't dominate it.
And so I was constantly worried about little niggling details.
I think had I been there by myself or just she and I there together, it would have been a much more enjoyable experience.
But I think that professionally, intellectually, it really was a marvelous experience.
But as a family man, as a concerned father,
I wouldn't want to go back there under those conditions again.
You know, how old were your sons then?
Well, this picture was taken when they were in Lima.
Clayton was four, and Bobby was nine.
When we got back, he was ten.
He was five.
Now, I still haven't found out, except perhaps some genes, how you happened to get into college.
How did you determine to go?
I can't explain it.
rationally, because there are so many things.
I was always very conscious of being Mexican-American and resenting the fact that somehow other people were better than us.
I suppose I was defensively aggressive, and still am to a certain extent.
And I suppose in a certain amount of wanting to go to college was sort of a show them kind of thing.
But then I always remember reading
I had a library card in my hometown library when I was seven, eight years old.
As quickly as I could get it, I had it.
So I've always had sort of a bench for books.
I've enjoyed it.
And I think this had a great deal to do with it.
I can't explain where did this come from.
Where did you go to college?
I began at the University of Wyoming.
And then I transferred to Utah State University.
And don't ask me why, because it's another one of those things I can't really explain rationally.
Except that I was doing more drinking and running around and studying, and I wanted to get away from the crowd of boys who were high school buddies.
How did you finance it?
GI Bill.
And I was a janitor at Sears and Roebuck for a couple of years.
So when were you in the service?
Korean War, 1950, 1954.
And then as soon as you got out, you started college.
GI Bill.
But did you go straight on for a doctorate?
Yes.
I finished my undergraduate in three years, three and a half, third years.
And then I got a fellowship at Stanford.
I got my master's at Stanford.
And I got a fellowship there, but unfortunately no waiver of tuition, so I had to get some financing.
By this time I was married and had a boy.
Where's your wife from?
She's from Ohio.
And she's... She's a gringa.
She's a gringa.
And then I got my PhD here in Colorado.
So it's working all the way through until... until graduate school.
And then in graduate school I got a very good...
fellowship first year as a Wilson, you know, not the school.
The Ford Foundation had to move the business.
I hadn't moved well.
And then I got the fellowship years at Colorado and the teaching assistantship.
And so that financed my way through.
I'm really very fortunate, you know, all the way through by having help, you know, from the government and then, you know, the people who gave me jobs.
There was a, if there's one
